text: coming up next is the science fiction radio show so stay with us this is the science fiction radio show a commentary on science fiction and fantasy and here are your hosts this is bill vernon and david carson jones slonzewski is a young biochemist who practices as a scientist and writes science fiction she brings into her writing another element from her life she is a practicing quaker slonzewski's first novel bears the title still forms on foxfield we asked her to explain the origin of the title foxfield is the name of the planet that was named after the quaker settled the planet and they named it after george fox who was the founder of the quaker religion still forms is a phrase that comes from a poem by whittier john greenleaf whittier who was a quaker and he would he wrote a poem which described the experience of being in a quaker meeting and he spoke of the still forms on either side that somehow breathed a special light and the still forms refers to the still forms of the people who were around him in the quaker meeting from the title and packaging of this novel the prospective reader might assume it is strictly a soft science book on the contrary the novel has a good deal of hard science woven in with good characterization slonzewski's aliens the commensals are well drawn they are sentient mobile plants that communicate by emitting and detecting volatile chemicals we discover that slonzewski came up with these aliens while in the laboratory listen to her describe her thoughts in my scientific work i've studied chemical communication among bacteria and it was sort of of interest to me supposing you could have an an alien intelligence that would communicate chemically uh through through things like pheromones almost um how would this work would it be possible and i tried to think what kind of of creatures these might be and and how they might work in different ways than our usual vertebrates mammals humans and so on and so it occurred to me they might have developed from plants for for instance uh they they might use something akin to plant hormones before slonzewski could write still forms on foxfield she had to find a way to incorporate these aliens with the quakers who were to be the human characters and i also was getting much interested in into into into quakerism i guess at a slightly later date and the two things finally meshed together and that was really the key to to the book was when i was able to combine those two ideas the idea of the aliens and the quakers and how they would interact and at that point that's when it became possible to move ahead with the book it seems unbelievable at first that science and quakerism can mix so easily here slonzewski explains a bit about quakerism and how for her the combination works the religion is basically christian it developed from um during the protestant reformation it was one of the protestant branches but at the same time it has become very universal as it has developed and quakers today see a great affinity with other somewhat universalist religions such as buddhism for example and i made that parallel in my book also and it is also a religion which scientists often find congenial because of the emphasis on the experience of the individual in science you you test the universe by making experiments uh quakers test the spiritual universe by meditation and and an inward seeking of truth an almost an inward type of experiment join us next time when we continue our talk with author joan slonzewski this has been the science fiction radio show production of the permian basin science fiction association produced in conjunction with odessa college in odessa texas this has been on your face study erica Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. a crisis, such as a death in the family, things like that. And in science fiction, very often people are portrayed in the far future with the idea that simply religion has died out and there's no more need for it anymore. Whereas I find that to be an unrealistic portrayal. It seems to me that there always will be people who will need religion, that it's a basic part of the human experience and that science is never going to completely replace that for people. Slonczewski has read a great deal of science fiction. We asked her what she watches out for when she reads a book featuring scientists at work. What I have my eye on really is the interaction between science and people. And that's the one thing that I think is the sign of an outstanding writer, is the one who can really show how science operates in real life, not how we would like it to operate in a fantasy life. I think Heinlein is, of course, the ideal example of that. In most of the good Heinlein stories, he will take a look at technology and yet show the human perspectives on it and show how ordinary people's lives are affected. Since Slonczewski is a young writer just beginning her career, we asked her what her advice is to aspiring writers. The most important thing in writing is to be distinctive. And by that I don't mean outrageous necessarily, but to find whatever you have that is unique in your experience. And at every step of your writing, try to write something that hasn't been written before. The second thing I would say is you just have to keep submitting what you write because... Now, I was very fortunate that the first publisher I sent my novel to happened to have an editor who really liked the idea and was taken with it. That's an unusual thing. Agatha Christie took 11 tries to get her first book published. You know, and there are all sorts of stories like that. So I would say those are the two main things. Try to be... To say the ordinary in a distinctive way. To write originally. And whatever you write, just keep submitting it to publication. Joan Slonczewski, a young scientist with great promise as a science fiction writer. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. before slonzewski could write still forms on foxfield she had to find a way to incorporate

and i also was getting much interested in into into into quakerism i guess at a slightly later date

And in science fiction, very often people are portrayed in the far future with the idea
that simply religion has died out and there's no more need for it anymore.
Whereas I find that to be an unrealistic portrayal.
It seems to me that there always will be people who will need religion, that it's a basic
part of the human experience and that science is never going to completely replace that for
people.
Slonczewski has read a great deal of science fiction.
We asked her what she watches out for when she reads a book featuring scientists at work.
What I have my eye on really is the interaction between science and people.
And that's the one thing that I think is the sign of an outstanding writer, is the one who
can really show how science operates in real life, not how we would like it to operate in
a fantasy life.
I think Heinlein is, of course, the ideal example of that.
In most of the good Heinlein stories, he will take a look at technology and yet show the human
perspectives on it and show how ordinary people's lives are affected.
Since Slonczewski is a young writer just beginning her career, we asked her what her advice is
to aspiring writers.
The most important thing in writing is to be distinctive.
And by that I don't mean outrageous necessarily, but to find whatever you have that is unique
in your experience.
And at every step of your writing, try to write something that hasn't been written before.
The second thing I would say is you just have to keep submitting what you write because...
Now, I was very fortunate that the first publisher I sent my novel to happened to have an editor
who really liked the idea and was taken with it.
That's an unusual thing.
Agatha Christie took 11 tries to get her first book published.
You know, and there are all sorts of stories like that.
So I would say those are the two main things.
Try to be...
To say the ordinary in a distinctive way.
To write originally.
And whatever you write, just keep submitting it to publication.
Joan Slonczewski, a young scientist with great promise as a science fiction writer.
